citation.article-title: Two new species of the genus Kitasatosporia, Kitasatosporia phosalacinea sp. nov. and Kitasatosporia griseola sp. nov.
citation.source: The Journal of General and Applied Microbiology

p.s: Description of Kitasatosporia griseola sp. nov.
Kitasatosporia griseola (gri se'o la. M. L. fem. adj. griseola gray)
Species-level classification
The species-level taxonomic studies of the two strains were carried out by comparing them with K. setalba, the type species of Kitasatosporia.
Morphology of aerial mycelia.
Figure 3 shows scanning electron-micrographs of aerial mycelia of three Kitasatosporia strains grown on glycerol-asparagine agar.
The morphology of the three strains was almost identical in that the sporophore is Rectiflexibiles and the spore shape is cylindrical.
However, compared with strain KA-338 and K. setalba, the aerial spores of strain AM-9660 were immature in septation and the spore surface was somewhat wrinkled as shown in Figs. 2a and 3b.
Cultural characteristics.
Table 2 shows the cultural characteristics of the three strains.
Abundant aerial mycelia were observed in these strains grown on yeast extract-malt extract agar, oatmeal agar and inorganic salts-starch agar.
The aerial mycelia of strain KA-338 and K. setalba was white on most media, and gray in strain AM-9660.
The three Kitasatosporia strains were different from each other in soluble-pigment production.
Physiological properties and carbon utilization.
Table 3 shows the physiological properties of three Kitasatosporia strains.
The strains are mesophiles and grew at pH 5.5-9.0.
The physiological properties of strain AM-9660 and K. setalba are similar to each other but different from those of strain KA-338 in nitrate reduction; coagulation of milk and antibiotic produced.
Table 4 shows the carbon utilization by Kitasatosporia strains.
In addition to carbon sources utilized by K. setalba, strain AM-9660 utilized raffinose, and strain KA-338 utilized raffinose, D-fructose, L-rhamnose and sucrose.
GC contents.
The GC contents (%) of strains KA-338 and AM-9660, and K. setalba were 66.6, 66.0 and 73.1, respectively.
The taxonomic comparison of the three Kitasatosporia strains is summarized in Table 5.
They are different from each other in some taxonomic properties.
Strains KA-338 and AM-9660 differ clearly from K. setalba in GC content, vegetative- mass color, soluble-pigment production and carbon utilization.
Strain KAFig 338 is different from strain AM-9660 in spore shape, color of aerial mycelium, nitrate reduction, coagulation of milk, utilizable carbons and antibiotics produced.

It is reasonable to conclude from the above data that strains KA-338 and AM- 9660 are new species of the genus Kitasatosporia, and they are named Kitasatosporia phosalacinea and Kitasatosporia griseola, respectively.
